Award.AwardTitle: RUI Collaborative: Biomechanics and Control of Landing in Toads
Award.AbstractNarration: The hindlimb muscles of frogs and toads have served as an exemplary model for understanding muscle?s role in powering propulsive movements like jumping. Anything that jumps must ultimately land, but unlike during jumping, where muscles produce the energy to accelerate the body, controlled landing requires muscles to dissipate energy to decelerate the body. The role of muscles during energy dissipation remains poorly understood. This research will reveal important principles associated with this locomotor activity. Terrestrial toads are outstanding at landing, using their forelimbs exclusively to decelerate their bodies. The proposed work will use toad landing as a model system for understanding how muscles control forelimb joint movements (shoulder, elbow and wrist) during and after impact. During human jumps, pre-landing activity in leg muscles is used to stiffen joints in preparation for landing, and is tuned to the expected time and magnitude of impact. Recent work demonstrates similarly prescient activity in muscles acting at the elbow joints of hopping toads in mid-air. The proposed work will address the generality of such tuned, pre-landing activity at other forelimb joints, and will specifically test the hypothesis that its utility lies in preventing muscles involved in energy dissipation from stretching to overly long lengths during landing, where injuries are most likely to occur. We will also examine the importance of visual and proprioceptive feedback in helping animals tune muscle activity to coordinate landing after hops of variable height and distance. By integrating biomechanics, muscle physiology and sensory biology this work will highlight fundamental principles governing controlled deceleration, an action common to most locomotor systems. Undergraduate students will be essential to the execution and presentation of this work, and by involving students and faculty from local community colleges, we will broaden direct participation in cutting-edge research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit

Our work had four major objectives, all related to how toads control deceleration and coordinate landing during routine hopping. The first objective was to assess how movements of the body while in mid-air help prepare the animal for impact. We were able to show that rapid hindlimb retraction after takeoff helps position the center of mass more anteriorly and in line with the ground reaction force, allowing the animal to balance on its forelimbs and decelerate after impact. Importantly, we showed a novel use of elastic energy storage in tissues, namely, the employment of elastic recoil during the recovery phase of the hop (i.e., after takeoff) to help pull/retract the hindlimbs back to the body, in turn moving the center of mass forward.

The second objective involved showing that toads' forelimb movements and the underlying forelimb muscle activity are tuned to the distance the animal hops. Animals use a control strategy that allows them to hit the ground with more extended forelimbs during longer hops, which is important in giving them a greater distance over which to decelerate. In addition, these longer hops are also often associated with more intense underlying muscle activity at the wrist and elbow so as to stiffen these joints more as landing forces increase.

The third objective was under the purview of my Co-PI and involved showing that the motor patterns and kinematic patterns described above lead to underlying fascicle strain patterns that keep muscle fibers in toad arms from becoming overly stretched as the animal decelerates during landing. Overly stretching muscle fibers can cause physical damage and so the control strategy of the toad seems to be oriented, in part, around preventing damage to muscles involved in dissipating energy during deceleration.

The fourth and final objective involved understanding the sensory systems involved in shaping the toad's coordinated landing behavior. We have shown that vision is not necessary, but that proprioceptive feedback from the hindlimbs as they push off during takeoff, as well as vestibular feedback on accelerations from the inner ear are likely critical in supporting coordinated movements associated with rapid deceleration in toad landing.

 

Broader impacts

This grant supported the work of 19 undergraduate students (including three transferring from community college to university), one graduate student, and also provided projects for a new faculty member at another college and her students. All undergraduates were exposed to the processes of animal care, experimental design and execution, data analysis and presentation. Many of these students joined me for poster presentations of the work at national meetings of the Society of Integrative and Comparative Biology. Two of the undergraduates were authors on a publication in the journal Biology Letters. In addition to disseminating our work at national meetings, I gave multiple talks at different colleges and universities in the Northeast and also presented in public forums including a Science Cafe in Hadley MA and a TEDx talk in Springfield MA.
